bibl.title: Report: A Possible Explanation of the Absence of Bubonic Plague from Cold Countries, by H. McG. Robertson, April 1923

div1.p: Robertson reports on plague distribution and speculates that its absence from cold climates is related to the absence of fleas in these areas.

div1.head: Report: A Possible Explanation of the Absence of Bubonic Plague from Cold Countries, by H. McG. Robertson, April 1923
div1.opener:
Miscell
Robertson
Plague
A Possible Explanation of the Absence of
Bubonic Plague from Cold Countries.
by
H. McG. Robertson, Surgeon, U. S. P. H. S.
div1.p:
A study of statistical reports of plague as published
in the Weekly Public Health Reports of the United States Public
Health Service will show that in the past twenty-six years
bubonic plague has spread in an east and west direction from
India until at the present time it may be found encircling the
globe in a rather broad band bounded, roughly, by the 35th degree
parallel north and south of the equator. This plague circle of
the globe was completed as far back as 1914 when this disease
appeared for the first time in one of the cities of our Southern
States. Bubonic plague has appeared north of the 35th parallel
north latitude rather extensively in southern Europe; in fact it
may be said that in this part of the world the 45th latitude north
is more probably the boundary. It is also noted that in our own
country this disease, appearing in San Francisco, is north of
the 35th parallel. Reference to climatic conditions along the
Mediterranean Coasts and in San Francisco will show that the
temperatures are markedly modified as compared with the temper-
atures in other countries of this same latitude. This of
course is due in great part to ocean currents and the warm waters
of the Mediterranean.

While during this 26 year period bubonic plague has
spread around the globe there has been no such corresponding
spread to the north and south of parallels 35 with one notable
-2-
exception. This exception is in the case of the British Isles;
yet here we see the climate modified to a great extent by the
Gulf stream. Notwithstanding this modification of climate and
in spite of the fact that bubonic plague has appeared in dif-
ferent places in Great Britain as often as twenty times during
the past twenty-six years there has been no general spread of
the disease during this time; there has been no spread at any
time from city to city, and during the past twelve months no
cases or deaths have been reported. In twenty-six years there
have been twenty-six deaths from the disease in question in all
parts of Great Britain, and this in spite of daily maritime
contact with the plague centers of the world and without until
recently any efforts along the lines of quarantine restrictions
or any extensive effort on the part of local authorities to
suppress these outbreaks.

It is seen from this study of the Public Health Reports
that bubonic plague during this term of years has spread alike
to countries which endeavored to prevent its entrance and to
those which made no such efforts; it is seen, too, that this
disease has failed to spread alike to colder countries which
made no effort to prevent its entrance as well as to those which
like our own North Atlantic Seacoast have made strenous effort
to prevent its ingress. In other words it appears that the
efforts of man to control the spread of this disease have been
of little or no avail. It would seem also that in this extended
period of time bubonic plague would have spread to northern
countries were it epidemiologically possible for it to have
-3-
done so. The fact that it has not so spread is not due
apparently to efforts on the part of man and it is equally
hard to look upon this phenomenon as accidental. This
brings up the question of the explanation of the failure
of this disease to spread to countries where the climate
is cold or relatively cold. This disease has never been
reported north of the 60th degree of latitude north; in
the western hemisphere it has never been reported north of
the 40th degree of latitude, except in Seattle. The existence
of this disease north of latitude 35 north has never in any
part of the world constituted a serious sanitary problem,
except in those warmer sections previously mentioned or in
ages past under conditions with which we cannot now be entirely
familiar.

It appears that little or no work, from an epidemio-
logical point of view, has been done which would explain the
absence, or practical absence, of bubonic plague from the
colder sections of the world. This absence is not believed
to be accidental, as before stated, nor is it believed in any
great degree to be the result of man's efforts.

In considering bubonic plague in its relation to human
beings, it is necessary, or usual, at this period of the world's
history to consider this disease in the rat as antecedent, and
necessary, to its spread to the human population. The time
may have been, when man, dressing in skins and furs and living
with lower animals in insanitary surroundings, contracted
-4-
bubonic plague through fleas coming directly from a member
of his own race. Such a transfer of this infection is not
now of sanitary significance, and the three factors - man,
the rat and the flea- are taken together in any epidemio-
logical study.

We see in the tropical sections of the world, that
human plague is or has been, reported in all months of the
year, and for numbers of years in succession. The inference
is, and this inference is supported by studies of the Indian
Plague Commission, that all three factors are present through-
out the entire year. The flea is the only factor which might
be considered variable, but this insect is found at all seasons,
though more plentiful during certain months. Man and the rat
must be active at all seasons in order to live. They are
relatively long-lived; they do not hibernate in any climate
and their young do not pass through the winter in the immature
state. Neither the human nor the rat population change
extensively in any given area during short periods. The adult
flea on the other hand lives usually not many months, and in
cold or cool climate the adult rarely passes through the winter.
The flea, as a species, is prevented from dying out in cold
countries by the ability of the immature forms to exist for
periods which may range to more than a year. These long
pupal stages are seen only in cool or cold weather. These
facts are borne out by the studies of the Indian Plague
Commission and by work done by the Bureau of Entomology of
the United States Department of Agriculture. In regard to
-5-
the absence of fleas, the adult form, in the winter months,
my observation of this phenomenon was confined to cats.
During two recent winters I was unable to find fleas on this
animal between December 15 and March 15, although the cats
in question spent the entire winter months indoors in warm
places and although the basements where they slept were,
during the previous summers, heavily infested with fleas.

It was this observation that led me to speculate as
to the probable absence of fleas from their rat hosts during
the cold months of the year and that farther led me to suspect
that in this absence of fleas was to be had an explanation
of the freedom of certain countries from outbreaks of human
cases of bubonic plague. During the past year I have advocated
making a flea survey of the cities of our Atlantic Coast in
order to determine definitely whether I was correct in thinking
this probable explanation the right one.

Should this flea survey show that fleas are relatively
abundant on rate at all seasons of the year, the absence of
bubonic plague would of necessity be accidental, as all three
factors needed in its spread would be present. If on the other
hand it was shown that during certain cold months no fleas, or
only an occasional flea, was found, an explanation of the
absence of human plague would be at hand. Rat plague introduced
into a locality where adult fleas were present would spread
among the rats, the rapidity of this spread being dependent
on the abundance of fleas and the larger or smaller number of
-6-
rats. If the fleas were present throughout the entire year, as
in the tropics, the infection among the rats must become so
extensive as eventually to result in human cases appearing. Rat
plague, introduced into a community where fleas are absent for
certain months, must of necessity die out when the flea disappears,
as one factor in the spread of the disease will be absent with
their disappearance.

The question as to whether human plague will appear in
a locality where rat plague must disappear at the beginning of
each winter can be answered only after consideration of several
factors. Among these are the number of fleas per rat in the
months when they are present; the number of months in which
fleas are found present; and the relative number of rats in the
locality under consideration. The character of the communication
with active plague centers might also be taken into account.
As regards the number of fleas per rat, this knowledge will be
valuable only when compared with a like knowledge of similar
conditions in localities where bubonic plague has prevailed
throughout the entire year, as in New Orleans, or some city in
India. The months in which fleas may be found on rats should be
fewer the farther north the locality studies is situated. In
regard to communication with plague centers, we have noted that
Great Britain, though in intimate maritime association with
India, has not suffered seriously.

In order to have some definite data based on statistical
reports, which might sustain my belief that the absence or
relative absence of fleas during the cold months determined the
absence of bubonic plague from such countries, a rather detailed
study of the reports of cases of plague as given in the Public
Health Reports for the past twenty-six years was undertaken.
A table was prepared giving the names of cities and countries
in which plague had been reported in the Public Health Reports
for the years 1897 to 1922 inclusive. Each year was divided
into two periods, corresponding to the semi-annual summaries
given in the last issues of the Public Health Reports for June
and December. Thus there were 52 semi-annual periods to theb
table. Each of the 52 volumes of the Public Health Reports
was consulted and the figures for the six months put in the
appropriate column under cities and countries. The totals thus
obtained have been used in preparing the tables which follow.
Upon securing from the U. S. Weather Bureau, Department of
Agriculture in Washington, a book entitled “The Climates of
the Continents”, by W. G. Kendrew, M. A., Oxford, published in
1922, it was possible to take the cities and countries of the
world in which plague had occurred and combine them in four
temperature groups, as shown later in tables 1, 2, 3, and 4.

It was in this way possible to show at a glance where
plague had actually occurred, how extensively and what was its
seeming relation to different temperatures. These temperature
periods also explain the apparent exceptions to the spread of
-8-
plague north of parallel 35 degrees north, mentioned in the
beginning of this article.

Tables one to eight follow, and after them a brief
explanation and discussion is given.

No question is raised in this statistical study of the
accuracy and completeness of the reports. It is obvious that
in some instances in certain countries they are far from
complete, yet there is no reason to suspect that any reported
cases are incorrect. It is more likely that fairly complete
returns have been made for those cities and countries in tables
one and two than for those in table three and four, as the
former are those which have for years paid more attention
to sanitary matters and from which correct reports of all
kinds might be expected.

div1.p:
Table I contains the principal seaports of the world in
which the mean mid-winter temperature is 35 degrees fahrenheit
or below. In only four of these cities has plague been report-
ed, the others being given because of the rather prevalent
belief that plague had already spread to the principal seaports
of the world. Two inland cities are also included because they
have reported plague.

Table II shows those cities of the world having a mean
mid-winter temperature of 36 degrees to 45 degrees fahrenheit
in which plague has been reported and the number of cases in
each.

Table III shows those cities and countries in which plague
has been reported in which the mean mid-winter temperature is
between 46 degrees and 55 degrees fahrenheit.

Table IV shows those countries and states having a mean
mid-winter temperature of 56 degrees fahrenheit and over in
all of which bubonic plague has been reported during the twenty-
six years under consideration.

Table V shows the total number of cases occurring in each
of the four temperature periods mentioned and the percentage
of cases reported for each one of these temperature divisions.
The percentages are given with and without including the cases
reported from India.

Table VI compares the percentages when computed for the
entire period of twenty-six years with those obtained when only
the last fifteen and one half years of that period are taken
into consideration.

Table VII shows the decrease in number of cases reported
in certain Chinese and Japanese cities where the mean mid-winter
temperatures decline progressively from south to north. It is
interesting to note that Peking, China, in twenty-six years,
has reported only two cases of plague though tens of thousands
of cases of the bubonic type occurred during that period in
South Eastern China, and two disastrous epidemics of pneumonic
plague visited Manchuria to the north during that time.

Table VIII shows the dates of beginning and ending of
those scattered outbreaks of plague which have occurred during
the last twenty-six years in cities with a mean mid-winter
temperature of 36 degrees to 45 degrees fahrenheit. It will
be noted that with scarcely any exceptions these outbreaks have
occurred in the late summer and fall. Being absent during the
winter months, it seems that only after incubation in the rat
population through the spring and early summer do these human
outbreaks occur. The time of these outbreaks seems to coincide
with the season in which fleas are known to be most plentiful.
It is also noted that there is a disappearance of this disease
not later than November or early December in nearly all cases
reported. This coincides with the idea I have advanced that
this disease would disappear with the disappearance of the fleas
at the beginning of the cold season, - up to a certain temperature
which remains to be determined.

In looking over tables I and II for facts that would tend
to discredit the deductions made as to bubonic plague occurring
-19-
and disappearing in accordance with the seasonal prevalence
of fleas, we are confronted with a few data that seem incon-
sistent with this idea.

In table I only four cities out of 27 have ever report-
ed plague. Of these four, Moscow reported 12 cases in two
outbreaks between December and February. If this was bubonic
plague it is incompatible with the belief that fleas disappear
in climates such as Moscow in cold weather. No mention is
made, however, in the Public Health Reports, as to whether
these cases were bubonic or pneumonic. In any event no further
cases were reported in Moscow in the summers following these
two outbreaks.

The cases occurring in St. Petersburg in May, 1910 are
also somewhat early in the year to be in accord with the belief
that fleas have not become plentiful at this season. As in
the case of the winter cases in Moscow no mention is made as
to these cases being bubonic or pneumonic. It is shown, how-
ever, in the Public Health Reports that in the years that these
winter cases were reported in St. Petersburg and Moscow, pneu-
monic plague was reported in Asiatic Russia and in the Astrakhan
District.

Three cases of plague occurred in Odessa in January,
1911 and can possibly be explained in the same manner as the
cases in Moscow and St. Petersburg.

In Peking, China the only two cases reported in twenty-
six years occurred in January. It is significant that these
-20-
two cases occurred in the winter in which 50000 deaths were
reported in Manchuria from pneumonic plague, and it is more
than possible that these two cases were pneumonic, though
they were not so reported.

The only city in table I in which plague was reported
as occurring in the summer and fall months is Odessa, Russia.
This disease was reported as follows:
1910 - July 18 to November 25 ---------- 140 cases
1911 - June 18 to August 8 ------------ 8 cases

In a grain shipping port such as Odessa, in a country where,
possibly, little attention is paid to sanitation and where
the human and rat populations may be both numerous and closely
associated it is possible for an outbreak of bubonic plague
to occur, and the last three reported for Odessa are probably
such.

Mention may be made here of the fact that it is only
in Russia and China that plague of any type has been reported
in localities having a mean mid-winter temperature of 35
degrees F. or below.

In table II there are mentioned twenty-five cities in
which bubonic plague has occurred in the period 1897 to 1922.
Of 1409 cases reported during this time 914 occurred in Kobe.
and Osaka, Japan.

The only reported outbreaks in this list which seem to
contravene the theory that the prevalence of fleas affects the
-21-
spread of bubonic plague will be mentioned below. It should
be noted, however, that we are dealing here with mean mid-
winter temperatures considerably higher than in table I, and
it is possible that while fleas may be definitely absent in
the winter months where the temperature is 35 degrees fahren-
heit or below, they may be sufficiently numerous in the next
temperature division - 36 degrees fahrenheit to 45 degrees
fahrenheit - to make possible the continuance of the disease
through the winter. Yet, the exceptions are so few as to
make it difficult to believe that some explanation of the
discrepancy might not be found if the correct records of the
cities involved were accessible.

Those outbreaks mentioned in this table which may cast
some doubt on the correctness of the theory advanced are as
follows:

Paris, January, 3 cases reported as suspected. They
possibly were not plague.

Cattaro, port of Cettinje, February, 3 cases reported
in French troops. These were possibly imported, but
it is not so stated.

Japan, in the nineteen outbreaks reported in five cities
in Japan all but two show the disease occurring between
May and December. Both of these were in Osaka; one
from January to April and the other from November to
May. This last was an outbreak of 297 cases, reported
in the June 30 summary of Public Health Reports as
-22-
occurring between November and May. Reference to the
weekly reports from January to June of that year show
that 234 of these cases occurred between November 17
and December 21; 31 cases between December 21 and
January 11 and the remaining 32 cases between January
12 and May 9, at the rate of about 2 cases a week.
While there was a decided drop in the number of cases
reported weekly - from 47 per week in November and
December to 2 per week from January 11 to May 9 -
during the cold months, the fact remains that in Osaka
human cases of bubonic plague were reported throughout
the winter. The mean January and February temperature
of Osaka is about 39.5 degrees fahrenheit. The December
and March temperatures are 41 degrees fahrenheit.
Whether this was an exceptionally warm winter in Japan
has not been determined.

It should be mentioned in considering the cities of
table I that the principal seaports have all more or less
intimate maritime relations with the plague centres of the
tropics and with those occassionally infected areas which are
found in the regions adjoining the tropics. In many of these
cities vessels have been reported from time to time in the
Public Health Reports as arriving with human cases of plague
aboard and it must be that many plague infected rats have
been introduced in the period of years under consideration.
In studying the outbreaks listed in table II, it is seen that
-23-
they are short-lived, apparently self-limited and practically
never result in a recurrence the following season after dying
out in the winter season. The only exception to this is the
outbreak in the Kobe-Osaka vicinity in the year 1908. Ex-
cluding the 914 cases reported in these two cities, only
483 cases of bubonic plague have been reported in the remain-
ing 23 cities in this group during a period of twenty-six
years.

The outbreaks shown in table III show in a general
way a rather definite seasonal prevalence for plague. This
seems not always to coincide with the rise and fall in
temperature and it is possible that at these temperatures
the prevalence of fleas is influenced both by rainfall and
temperature variations. Further study of the Public Health
Reports and flea surveys of localities in this temperature
division are necessary to make any accurate deductions as
to what it is reasonably possible to predict for such localities.
It is, however, obvious that some rather strong influence has
been at work in localities even of these high temperatures
to limit the spread of bubonic plague in 23 cities and countries
over a period of twenty-six years to less than 10000 cases,
nearly two thirds of which have been reported from two
localities, Bagdad and vicinity and South Africa.

The periodic and infrequent occurrence of bubonic
plague in cities and countries of this group is in rather
striking contrast to the almost constant presence of this
disease in the countries which are mentioned in the last group.
-24-
These last are the really tropical countries and it is in
these that 94.5 per cent of cases reported in twenty-six
years have occurred. Bubonic plague has been reported
continuously for the past twenty-six years, or since first
reported, in the following countries: India, Java, Ceylon,
Egypt, South East China, Peru, Brazil and Equador. This is
in rather marked contrast to its irregulat periodicity in
those cities and countries in the third temperature division
which have a lower mean mid-winter temperature. It is in
much more marked contrast to those cities mentioned in
tables one and two where bubonic plague occurs at rare
intervals, and at definite seasons in most instances.

Mention must be made of the report of plague in two
sections of the world where it has been often reported and
where it has caused tens of thousands of deaths. These two
areas are Manchuria and the districts surrounding the Caspian
Sea. In this study it has not been possible to examine the
weekly records of cases reported. The semi-annual summaries
of cases given in the Public Health Reports sometimes refer
to the outbreaks in these regions as “pneumonic”, but not
always so. From the relatively short periods in which so
many cases and deaths were reported, and the exceedingly
high mortality rate mentioned the belief is strong that all
or most of this plague was of the pneumonic variety. Further
detailed study will be necessary, however, should more accurate
data as to the reports from these areas be desired.

All of the 35500 cases of plague reported in Japan with
the exception of something over 1000 were reported from the
Island of Formosa.

The more obvious conclusions to be drawn from this dis-
cussion and these tables are:

1st. that bubonic plague is essentially a disease of hot
climates, and that having been introduced into tropical
countries it tends to persist indefinitely.

2nd that outside of the immediate tropics, this disease is
rather definitely limited in the extent to which it will spread.

3rd that in countries with a mean mid-winter temperature of
45 degrees fahrenheit or below bubonic plague is occasional,
accidental and distinctly self-limited and that it seems
possible for it to occur in the colder regions only for short
periods under unusual conditions.

As to the bearing of this study on my deduction that
the seasonal prevalence of fleas regulates the spread of
bubonic plague, it appears to me to sustain the belief; other-
wise it becomes necessary to find some equally reasonable
explanation for the absence of bubonic plague from cold countries.

Any estimate of the practical results that would ensue
from a determination of the correctness of the theory advanced
in the article, and the conclusions drawn therefrom must await
confirmation by an actual and comparative flea survey of any
given locality.
